abstract.text: A control that displays a color value and lets the user change that color value.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object lets people select colors from your interface. Incorporate this type of control if your app supports custom color selection. For example, a drawing app might include a color well to let someone choose the color to use when drawing. A color well control displays the currently selected color, and interactions with the color well display interfaces for selecting new colors.

When you create a color well programmatically or in Interface Builder, specify the appearance and interaction style you want. The color well supports color selection using a color picker popover or the system

object. When someone selects a new color in one of these interfaces, the color well updates its selected color to match. You can also provide your own color selection process using a custom action and update the color yourself.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A standard user interface for selecting color in an app.
An abstract superclass that implements the default color picking protocol.
A bar item that provides a system-defined color picker.
A control that displays a color value and lets the user change that color value.
Constants that specify the appearance and interaction modes for a color well.
Activates the color well, displays the color panel, and synchronizes the two UI elements.
The currently selected color for the color well.
The appearance and interaction style to apply to the color well.
Deactivates the color well.
Draws the area inside the color well at the specified location without drawing borders.
The image to display on the button portion of a color well that adopts the expanded style.
Creates a color well that adopts the specified appearance style.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the color well is currently active.
A Boolean value that determines whether the color well has a border.
The action to perform when someone clicks in the color area of the color well.
The target object that defines the action you want to perform when someone interacts with the color well.
A Boolean value that determines whether the color picker supports alpha values.
Changes the currently selected color to the color of the specified object.
A specialized view, such as a button or text field, that notifies your app of relevant events using the target-action design pattern.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
